Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the step-parent needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: I stared at the notice pinned to the break room wall, the words “Optional Training Session – Next Week” jumping out at me. My foreman said it could lead to more hours and maybe a shot at a team lead position, but it meant staying late, missing dinner, and paying for a sitter. At home, my partner and I had just sat down with the bills, the home loan repayment looming like a storm cloud. I promised I’d do everything to keep us afloat, to be the steady hand my stepdaughter could count on. But the training wasn’t paid, and every hour away from home was another hour I couldn’t help with homework or reassure her that things would be okay. My crew expected me to step up, to show I was committed, but my family needed me present, not just as a provider but as a parent. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding more than I had to give, and I stood there, torn, unable to move.
